thread.title: Goff turnovers costly as Cal loses at Utah
thread.title_full: Goff turnovers costly as Cal loses at Utah

author:
Jeff Faraudo

jfaraudo@bayareanewsgroup.com
title: Goff turnovers costly as Cal loses at Utah
text:
Goff turnovers costly as Cal loses at Utah By Jeff Faraudo Posted: 10/10/2015 10:52:19 PM PDT Updated: 10/10/2015 11:51:25 PM PDT SALT LAKE CITY -- With the nation watching, quarterback Jared Goff delivered the worst game of his career Saturday night, being intercepted five times as No. 23 Cal melted under the spotlight in a 30-24 loss to No. 5 Utah. 
Touted all week by national commentators as a Heisman Trophy contender, Goff was picked off four times in the first half. Interception No. 5 came with 7:24 left when he underthrew Kenny Lawler and was picked off by Dominique Hatfield at the Utah 18-yard line. 
"We're going to have to show how we respond to this," Goff said. "It was the first big test for us. Unfortunately, I played terribly." 
The Bears could not overcome six turnovers in the showdown of the Pac-12's two remaining unbeaten teams in front of a capacity crowd of 47,798 at Rice-Eccles Stadium. 
Cal (5-1, 2-1 Pac-12) was trying to reach 6-0 for the first time since 1950. 
The Utes (5-0, 2-0) scored 17 points off Cal turnovers. 
"Well, that was a tough one," Cal coach Sonny Dykes said. "Our kids played really hard. I'm disappointed for them. We just made too many mistakes to win the football game. We turned the ball over six times, but (Utah) had a lot to do with that." 
Cal got the ball one last time at its own 5-yard line with 4:52 left, and Goff made the Utes sweat. He converted three third-down plays to extend the drive, using his arm and his legs to move to the Utah 21. 
But on fourth-and-5 with 26 seconds left, Utah's Boobie Hobbs stepped in front of Darius Powe to knock down Goff's final pass of the night. Advertisement 
"We turned the ball over six times and still had a chance to win," Goff said. 
An ESPN national audience tuned in to watch Goff, who had thrown 15 touchdowns and just four interceptions in five previous victories. In his 30th career start, he suffered a nightmarish game. 
He finished 25 for 47 for 340 yards with two touchdowns. 
Dykes said Goff "just struggled a little bit tonight." 
"We all wanted to win really badly, especially Jared," Dykes continued. "Sometimes when you want to win really badly, you might try to do a little too much." 
Instead of Goff, the game's star was Utah running back Devontae Booker, who rushed for 222 yards and two touchdowns, surpassing 2,000 yards for his career. 
The Bears have next week off, then play at No. 20 UCLA on Thursday, Oct. 22. They return home to play USC on Halloween before visiting Oregon the following week. 
Cal still needs just one more victory to become bowl eligible for the first time since 2011. 
"We'll look forward to getting it right the next game," Bears defensive end Kyle Kragen said. 
A 4-yard touchdown run by Tre Watson with 2:03 left in the third quarter got the Bears within 27-24. Utah stretched its lead to 30-24 on a 39-yard field goal by Andy Phillips with 12:07 left. 
The Bears, who had turned the ball over just 10 times in five previous games, gave it away five times in the first half. Four of those were interceptions by Goff, who hadn't thrown more than two in a game since his debut as a freshman against Northwestern in the 2013 opener. 
ESPN reported that no other FBS quarterback in the nation had thrown four in a game this season. 
The first of Goff's picks went through the hands of target Kenny Lawler, but the others were his fault: one thrown into tight coverage, another on an underthrown deep pass to Bryce Treggs and the fourth on a tipped screen pass. 
Cal survived its first three turnovers, allowing the Utes to cash them in for just three points. But Goff's last two picks of the half set up two touchdowns in a span of 1 minute, 39 seconds. 
Utah's Travis Wilson threw a 54-yard TD strike to wide-open cornerback-turned-receiver Cory Butler-Bird with 3:26 left before Booker scored on a 4-yard run for a 24-10 lead with 1:47 remaining. 
Goff rallied the Bears, completing five straight passes -- including a 50-yarder to Stephen Anderson -- to cut the deficit in half on a 1-yard TD toss to Darius Powe with 26 seconds left. 
Cal running back Daniel Lasco, who had played just one half over the previous three games because of a hip injury, fumbled on his first carry and did not play again. oct. 22 game Cal (5-1, 2-1 Pac-12) at UCLA (4-1, 1-1), 6 p.m. ESPN
